Altruism is the act of being kind and helping others, even if it means sacrificing your own interests. This behavior is generally viewed as good and moral in society. However, Ayn Rand, an American philosopher, challenges this perspective. She believes that people should prioritize their own interests first because that's the only way they can survive in the world. She thinks that nature does not guarantee our survival, so we must take care of ourselves to live.

Rand argues that being completely unselfish and giving everything to others will ultimately harm oneself and society in the long run. She also believes that selflessness could be manipulated to promote the idea that the individual does not matter, and that the state or collective is more important. This, in turn, could be used to justify the suppression of individual rights and freedoms by dictators. In fact, some historians believe that the Nazi government used altruism to promote their ideology.

Despite being controversial, Ayn Rand's ideas are significant because they challenge conventional beliefs about selfishness and altruism. By reversing the traditional view of selfishness as negative and altruism as positive, Rand's ideas have contributed to the ongoing debate about the role of the individual and collective good in society.
